descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: We will begin with an overview of contemporary approaches to Christian ethics, with some attention to their historical background, and then move to discussions of guidelines for ethical analysis and action that have been proposed by representative Roman Catholic, mainline Protestant, and conservative Evangelical moralists.  Topics to be discussed include war, economy, capital punishment, and sexuality.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
PREREQUISITES: One course in philosophy or a western religious tradition, or junior standing, or permission of instructor.    A permission number is required for frosh and sophomores.
No P/N.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will learn how to recognize, characterize, and describe a variety of Christian approaches to moral thought.  They will also be familiar with contemporary Christian arguments on four important moral issues.  Both skills will enable students to read "between the lines" to decipher media presentations of Christian moral positions.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Discussion: Daily discussion of readings
Films / videos: Occasional topical films and clips
Group work: Small group discussion; no group projects
Lecture: Daily short lectures
Readings: Daily readings
Writing assignments: Reading reflections, current events reflections, final paper

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Attendance: Part of participation grade
Class participation: 20%
Paper, final: 35%
Writing assignments: 45%: reflections on readings, current events
